de.esoco.ewt.component

Class Component

  • java.lang.Object
    • de.esoco.ewt.component.Component
  • All Implemented Interfaces:
    de.esoco.lib.property.HasId<java.lang.String>
    Direct Known Subclasses:
    Calendar, Composite, Container, Control, Label, ProgressBar, Website

    public abstract class Component
extends java.lang.Object
implements de.esoco.lib.property.HasId<java.lang.String>
    This is the base class for all GEWT components.

    • Nested Class Summary

      Nested Classes 
      Modifier and Type Class and Description
      class  Component.ComponentEventDispatcher
      This is the base class for event dispatcher implementations that forward GWT events to GEWT listeners.

        See Also:

      • applyStyle

        public void applyStyle(StyleData rNewStyle)
        Applies a certain style to this component underlying GWT widget. This method is normally invoked by the framework when a component is created. Not all EWT implementations may support the application of (all) styles to components that already exist.

        This method should be overridden by subclasses that need to apply subcomponent-specific styles.

        Parameters:
        rNewStyle - The style to apply to this instance

      • createImage

        public Image createImage(java.lang.Object rID,
                         java.lang.Object rImageReference)
        Creates a new image object that is associated with this component. In certain EWT implementations images are based on limited system resources and the implementation therefore needs to perform cleanup operations on such resources when a component's lifecycle ends. This is done automatically for images if they are created through this method. If the component's lifecycle ends all associated images will be disposed.

        Applications that need to manage image objects independently from component lifecycles must create these images through the context method UserInterfaceContext.createImage(Object) instead. For an overview of the supported types of image data see the documentation of that method.

        Because of the ID parameter multiple images can be managed for the same component. If a new image is created with an identifier that has already been used for a previous image that previous image will be disposed. If an application decides that an component-associated image is no longer needed it may invoke the image's dispose() method any time.

        Parameters:
        rID - The identifier for the new image
        rImageReference - sImage rImageData The input stream that will provide the image data
        Returns:
        A new Image instance that is associated with this component

      • setProperties

        public void setProperties(java.lang.Object rProperty)
        Allows to set a component property or even multiple properties. This is a limited implementation of the standard EWT method. The standard method accepts a variable argument list that can contain multiple properties. This implementation only supports a single argument (due to the lack of variable argument lists in GWT). But it is still possible to set multiple similar named properties with the corresponding prefix (see below).

        The method argument can be either an Image object or a string that describes the property. An image object will be set as the component image if the component implements the ImageAttribute interface. A string argument will be parsed according to several criteria: If it doesn't start with a special prefix char it will simply be set as the component's text if the component implements the TextAttribute interface.

        Property strings that are prefixed with a dollar sign ('$') will be automatically expanded from the context resource by means of the method UserInterfaceContext.expandResource(String). If a component doesn't implement the attribute interfaces that are necessary to set a property the property will be ignored.

        A property string that starts with a special prefix character will be treated as described in the following list which shows the subset of prefixes that are recognized in GEWT:

        • #<file>: The remaining string will be used as the name (and path) of an image file to be used as the element's image. If the string is preceded with the resource prefix '$' the filename will be retrieved from the context resource. If the component implements the ImageAttribute interface an image will be created from the file and set on the component.
        • +<$key>: The trailing string must be a resource key (i.e. prefixed with '$') that will be used to look up the component text and, with the automatically added prefix 'im', the component image.
        • @<$key>: a resource key for image (im) and tool tip (tt)
        • %<$key>: a resource key for text, image (im), and tool tip (tt)
        • ~<string>: This is an escape that allows to prevent strings that start with prefixed characters from being transformed. The '~' character will be stripped from the string and the remaining string will be used as a plain string that will be set as the component's text.

        The following list contains some examples of property strings:

        • "Cancel": a simple text string to be set as the component text
        • "$btOk": a resource key for the component text
        • "#/res/img/info.png": a path to an image file
        • "#$imInfo": a resource key referencing an image file
        • "+$Copy": a resource key for component text and image (expanded to $imCopy)
        • "~!$string": the escaped text "!$string"
        Parameters:
        rProperty - The property to set on the component

      • setToolTip

        public void setToolTip(java.lang.String sText)
        Sets the text of the tool-tip. If the string contains a resource key it will be expanded.
        Parameters:
        sText - The new tool tip text or NULL for no tool-tip

      • setVisibility

        public void setVisibility(boolean bVisible)
        Set the visibility of this component. This will only affect the display of the component but not it's rendering in the parent container's layout. To prevent the rendering completely setVisible(boolean) should be used instead.
        Parameters:
        bVisible - TRUE if visible

      • setVisible

        public void setVisible(boolean bVisible)
        Set the component's display status that also affects layout of the parent container. To only affect the rendering of the component itself the method setVisibility(boolean) can be used instead.
        Parameters:
        bVisible - bRender TRUE to display the component, FALSE to hide it

      • createWidget

        protected com.google.gwt.user.client.ui.IsWidget createWidget(StyleData rStyle)
        Creates the GWT widget for this instance with the corresponding widget factory returned by EWT.getWidgetFactory(Class). Subclasses that override this method or layouts that need information about this component's hierarchy can invoke getParent() to access the parent container but should be aware that this component hasn't yet been added to the parent at this point. The method getContext() can also be invoked to access the UserInterfaceContext.
        Parameters:
        rStyle - The component style
        Returns:
        The new widget

      • getTextPosition

        protected AlignedPosition getTextPosition(StyleData rStyle)
        Determines the aligned position for text from the text alignment stored in a style data object. If no text alignment is set the returned value will be AlignedPosition.RIGHT.
        Parameters:
        rStyle - The style data object
        Returns:
        The aligned position of the text
